Wellbeing.title: Give to {others}
Wellbeing.content:
Acts of {giving} can help {improve} your mental health and by:

:-- creating {positive} feelings and a sense of reward - giving you a feeling of purpose and {self-worth} -- Improving {friendships} with others --:

Wellbeing.title: {Connect} with others
Wellbeing.content:
{Healthy relationships} are crucial for your {mental health}. They can contribute to:

:-- Helping you to build {confidence} -- Giving you an opportunity to relate {positive} events in your life -- Providing emotional {support} for yourself and others --:

Wellbeing.title: Be physically {active}
Wellbeing.content:
Being {active} is not only great for your physical {health} and {fitness}. Evidence also shows it can contribute to mental wellbeing by:

:-- Allowing you to {connect} to others -- Helping you aim high and set {goals}. -- Release {endorphins} causing improved mood --:

Wellbeing.title: {Learn} new skills
Wellbeing.content:
{Learning} new skills can improve your mental wellbeing by:

:-- {Boosting} confidence and sense of purpose -- Helping you {achieve} future {goals} -- Allowing you to {broaden} your skill set --:

Wellbeing.title: Who can {help}?
Wellbeing.content:
You {don't} have to suffer in silence. Here are some people that will always be there to {help}:

:-- www.{youngminds}.org.uk -- www.{nspcc}.co.uk -- www.{time-to-change}.org.uk -- www.{mentalhealth}.org.uk --:

Wellbeing.title: Have a balanced {diet}
Wellbeing.content:
Your {diet} should include:

:-- 55% {Carbohydrates}: pasta, rice -- 15% {Proteins}: meat, nuts -- 30% {fats} (mainly unsaturated): avocado -- 5 pieces of {fruit or veg} a day -- 2.5 litres of {water} a day --:

Wellbeing.title: {Effects} of drugs & alcohol
Wellbeing.content: {Smoking} is the biggest cause of {preventable} deaths in England, accounting for nearly 80,000 deaths each year. Heavy {drinking} can also increase your blood pressure and blood cholesterol levels, both of which are major {risk} factors for heart attacks and strokes.

Wellbeing.title: Limit your {weight}
Wellbeing.content: The formula for BMI is weight (kg) divided by height (m2). You can find plenty of resources to help with this online, on websites such as: {www.nhs.uk/conditions/obesity/}

Wellbeing.title: Get some {exercise}
Wellbeing.content: {Exercise} releases {endorphins} and other happy hormones which promote a feeling of wellbeing. Do some form of exercise for {20 mins} each day

Wellbeing.title: Get lots of {rest}
Wellbeing.content:
A {minimum} of {8} hours of sleep is required per night in order to be ready for a day of hard work

Go on {Spotify} and search Sleep as a Genre.

Revision.title: Revise... Test... {Rest}
Revision.content:
Here's our {3 step} plan for {success}:

1-- {Revise} for about {35 minutes}. This could be active revision, instead of just making notes -- {Test} yourself for about {15 minutes}. You could use Quizlet for this, ask a friend or find some exam questions online -- Take a {rest} for about {10 minutes} - do whatever you want! --1

Revision.title: Get it over and {done} with
Revision.content: :-- {Do not} leave revision to the last minute - it never goes well. -- Make notes as you go and set {regular goals} for yourself. -- {Revisit} your notes regularly after making them. -- If you’re tight for {time}, you can watch videos on {2x speed}. --:

Revision.title: Learning to {focus}
Revision.content:
Being {focused} while revising can save {you} a lot of time, so here’s a {3 step} plan to keep focused:

1-- Avoid learning in your {room}. Instead, find somewhere quiet with {fewer distractions}. -- Learn what is {really} important. Sticking to a {textbook} keeps you learning the right information. -- {Evaluate} your results. If a test goes badly, try to find a {strategy} to avoid making the same mistakes in the next one. --1

Revision.title: Food {Glorious} Food
Revision.content:
Before you start {revising}, make sure you have fully charged to Maximise efficiency.

{Foods} that help revision:

:-- Fish -- Blueberries -- Seeds and nuts -- Dark chocolate --:

Revision.title: Tracking your {time}
Revision.content: :-- Set {time limits} in your most used apps. -- {Decrease} the time limits nearer to exam season. -- If your phone Make sure to give yourself a little {free time} in between revision sessions, though. --:

Revision.title: {Little} bits over a {long} time
Revision.content:
:-- Revise in {short bursts} over longer time periods rather than doing a marathon right before an exam. -- This makes it easier to revise and you remember the information better --:

{Fact}: Repeating something 30 times moves it to {long term memory}.

Revision.title: {Last minute} revision
Revision.content:
Before you do an exam, you should aim to have {already} made and learnt your notes. In the days leading up to an important exam, make sure to do plenty of {practice questions} and (most importantly) {learn} from the mistakes you make on them. Here are some useful links to help with this:

:-- www.physicsAndMathsTutor.com -- www.savemyexams.co.uk --:

Revision.title: Don’t neglect {vocab}
Revision.content:
One of the most time consuming parts of revising is learning vocab, but it is {vital} in showing your {proficiency} in a subject.

There are plenty of resources online to help learning vocab such as {Quizlet} and {Memrise}.

Whichever way you prefer to learn the vocab, be sure to start it {now}, rather than leaving it to another day

Revision.title: {Studying} the {senses}
Revision.content: :-- {Experiment} with {visual learning} to aid your revision. -- It is {scientifically proven} that writing in different {colours} (e.g. blue) improve memory of what you have written. -- Make lots of diagrams, videos & songs, and recordings of your notes. --:

Revision.title: {Work} hard; {play} hard
Revision.content: During exam season, you should be doing plenty of revision, but it is imperative that you {rest} as well. Giving yourself a break at the {end of the day} to do whatever you want gives you something to {look forward} to; {recharge} your batteries; and {improve concentration} for the next day.
